reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s optimism about moral trade via “resource compatibility” (Section 3), which is an important but not load-bearing pillar: the essay’s case for trade also rests on other bases (time preference, risk, institutional lowering of transaction costs, hybrid goods), and it already flags that linear/maximizing views may be poorly resource-compatible and that trade may fail in such regimes. So centrality is moderate. Strength is limited because it mostly restates (in sharper form) a failure mode the essay already discusses (linear-in-resources maximizers making compromise hard), and it doesn’t show that trade generally collapses (e.g., partitioning, differing constraints, or genuinely non-fungible/agent-relative values can preserve gains from trade). Correctness is mixed: the “computronium/fungibility under high optimization” point is often apt for certain maximizing objectives, but it’s overstated as a general limit and ignores value systems that treat specific structures/locations/histories as intrinsically non-substitutable. The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: High optimization makes all resources zero-sum, collapsing trade compatibility
